titleStmt.title: [Letter] 1815 Feb. 26, St. Stephens [Alabama, to] James Winchester, Mobile [Alabama] / Geo[rge] S[trother] Gaines : a machine readable transcription of an image
titleStmt.author: Gaines, Geo. S.

publicationStmt.publisher: University of Tennessee Special Collections Library

For all other use contact the Tennessee State Library and Archives, 403 Seventh Avenue North, Nashville, TN 37243-0312. (615) 741-2764.

bibl.title: 1815 Feb. 26, St. Stephens [Alabama, to] James Winchester, Mobile [Alabama] / Geo[rge] S[trother] Gaines
bibl.author: Gaines, Geo. S.
bibl.note: This is a letter from George Strother Gaines to Brigadier General James Winchester, dated February 26, 1815. Gaines is in charge of the Choctaw agency. Gaines expresses concern that the British are lying about their desire to end the war. He also writes that his health is not good.

projectDesc.p: Created for the University of Tennessee Digital Library

editorialDecl.p: Quotation marks retained as data except inside q tags
Errors in transcription of the printed text controlled with X-Metal 2.1 spell-checker; text has also been thoroughly proofread.
Corrections and normalization represented by editorial tags.
Catchwords and directional notes such as "turn page over" have been omitted.

refsDecl.p: ID attributes provided for only those pages, chapters, or illustrations toward which a reference or figure points.

div1.p: I thank you for your letter for the 22nd Inst I had the pleasure to receive it last night.

I am not apt to put the worst construction on the professions or acts of any man or set of men, Yet the British officers have since the commencement of the war given us so many instances of the little respect they pay to their words or their honors, That I am not clear of suspicion that their humane proposition of a cessation of hostilities may be entended to do us no good and I doubt you and Genl McIntosh will be prepared to meet the worst that can follow

I have at the request of Major Blue supplied Capt Browen and the Chickasaw guard and their prisoners for several weeks with provisions but with much difficulty. I beg that some others disposition may
be made of them;_ my state of health will not allow us to do much more for them.

closer.salute:
I have the honor to be your
obt & Humbt servant
